column3:
These were the warning my patch fixes:
src\main.cpp: In member function 'bool CBlock::ConnectBlock(CBlockIndex*, CCoinsViewCache&, bool)':
src\main.cpp:warning: unknown conversion type character 'l' in format [-Wformat]
src\main.cpp:warning: unknown conversion type character 'l' in format [-Wformat]
src\main.cpp:warning: too many arguments for format [-Wformat-extra-args]

Looks like a bug in Microsoft printf family of functions :(

ACK for 0.7.2 & master
Thanks for taking a look and I wanted to clarify why I patched it :).\n

Please fix the commit message.  The one-line summary of your change, as it appears in "git shortlog" and other tools, is wholly useless:  "fix pull #2018"

That is utterly meaningless without further research; it tells nothing about what code is modified, or how it was modified, or why it needed modification.

We use "git shortlog" to generate summaries for release notes and other purposes.  T
How is this a bug in the Microsoft printf function @Luke-Jr?\n
@laanwj %lld is standard C printf format, but not supported by Microsoft's printf: http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&atid=102435&aid=1963136&group_id=2435\n
Ooh, okay something made by MS is incompatible to the standards, now that's a now one, let's call the press :)\n

I still don't get those warnings though.
We define:

```
#ifndef PRI64d
#if defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__MSVCRT__)
#define PRI64d  "I64d"
#define PRI64u  "I64u"
#define PRI64x  "I64x"
#else
#define PRI64d  "lld"
#define PRI64u  "llu"
#define PRI64x  "llx"
#endif
#endif
```

Which means that in the case of MS, we use "special" retarded character sequences. The thing is, there is
@laanwj The original code which Diapolo is referring to used %lld; he replaced that with PRI64u, but it needs to be PRI64d since the argument is signed.\n
Right, I get it now, thanks\n
@jgarzik Sorry, yes it was a weak commit message :), fixed it!\n
